title: Dina Asher-Smith promises not to let fame game keep her away from the fast show
text:

Dina Asher-Smith vowed that success would not change her as she flew home with a fistful of medals - and plans to decorate her kitchen, writes Alex Spink in Doha.

Rather than paint the town red after becoming the first Briton ever to win three medals at a single world championships, she instead decided to paint her kitchen purple.

“I’ve been taking pictures of the coffee shop here in the hotel,” said the sprint sensation. “I want to make the kitchen in my flat look like it, with the blue and the purple. I’m serious!”

Asher-Smith had been installed as the poster girl for next year’s Tokyo Olympics before adding relay silver to her 200 metres gold and 100m silver on Saturday night.

And few will argue with the choice of world athletics boss Seb Coe given the way the 23-year-old backed up her triple gold medal-winning performance at last year’s Europeans.

Already second favourite behind Ben Stokes for SPOTY, she is going to be in high demand in the nine months between now and flying to Japan.

But she pledged: “I will keep being me. If that means great things happen then they do, if it doesn’t then hey-ho. I have always been about running fast.

“I have mixed emotions about my profile going up. I am not one to be like, ‘look at me’, I am not that kind of person who is “look at this, look at that”.

“It is one of the things that I’ve had to get used to, the extra attention, people wanting selfies when I am warming up. But that is not why I came into the sport.

(Image: Getty Images)

"I like to run and I want to keep doing that and having fun. Keep being me on the track. That means eye liner, lipsticks, scrunchies, smiling and being clumsy!”

Asher-Smith paid tribute to team mates Asha Phillip, Ashleigh Nelson and Daryl Neita, without whom her third medal of the week would not have been possible.

These are all experienced athletes who will keep their friend grounded and, anyway, Asher-Smith is savvy enough to work out that if she gets distracted from her day job, the trapping will quickly melt away.

(Image: PA)

“I know you only get this platform because you are running fast and successful,” she acknowledged. “I’m very clear that you have to keep doing that.”

Athletics owes her a debt of gratitude for sprinkling stardust on an event beset by its fair share of problems - from tiny crowds early on, to extreme weather conditions, to the Salazar doping scandal.

The British team were relieved to have her too given that otherwise they would have got nowhere near the ‘minimum’ medal target, set by UK Sport, of seven.

(Image: REUTERS)

Despite falling two short, team captain Richard Kilty claimed they can confidently expect to win “10 to 12” at the Olympics.

“That’s got to be the target,” he said. “That’s not being ambitious.”
